document_title: Frontal sinus mucocele: Causes, symptoms and diagnosis
subsection_name: u-nhay-xoang-tran.json_3_Methods of diagnosing frontal sinus mucocele
subsection_content:
Dr. Thuy Hang said that the diagnosis of frontal sinus mucocele will be based on history, physical examination and imaging.
1. CT scan
There are three criteria for CT diagnosis of a frontal sinus mucocele including:
The mass has uniform density, clear margins, and peritumoral bone destruction; Sinus wall erosion with marginal fibrosis is also a sign.
2. MRI scan
Often indicated in the differential diagnosis of complicated cases that cannot be identified by CT scan.
Cases requiring an MRI include:
Dermoid cyst.; Langerhans cell histiocytosis.; Fungal infections and tuberculosis; Cholesterol granuloma in the forehead - orbit.; Other uncommon tumors.
Typically, frontal sinus myxoma tends to be bright on T1-weighted images compared to the brain and hyperdense on T2-weighted images.
